title: What if hope isn't optimism, but faithfulness in the dark?
teaser: 57% are pessimistic about 2026. Political violence at 1970s levels. Is there hope beyond optimism?

panels.heading: THE DEATH OF OPTIMISM
panels.content:
57% of Americans are pessimistic about 2026.

Two years ago, 56% were optimistic. The reversal happened fast.

Political violence at levels not seen since the 1970s. 150+ politically motivated attacks in the first half of 2025 alone. Climate tipping points passed. AI threatening jobs, truth, meaning itself.

Democracy feels fragile. The economy feels rigged. The future feels canceled.

Optimism says "it'll all work out."

But you can't say that anymore with a straight face.

The doomers were right. The optimists were naive.

So what's left when optimism dies?

panels.heading: THE MYTH OF POSITIVE THINKING
panels.content:
You tried positive thinking, didn't you?

Gratitude journals. Manifestation. Affirmations in the mirror. "Good vibes only."

You posted inspirational quotes. You told yourself "everything happens for a reason." You toxic-positivity'd your way through the collapse.

But it didn't work.

Because optimism is fragile. It depends on circumstances being fixable.

And when 47.9 million are food insecure, when political violence is normal, when the systems are failing—optimism is a luxury you can't afford.

**Hope is not optimism.**

Hope is something else entirely.

panels.heading: THE COST OF DESPAIR
panels.content:
But despair isn't the answer either.

Despair says "it's over, why bother?"

So you doomscroll. You numb out. You stop caring because caring hurts too much.

You've accepted the apocalypse as background noise. You joke about climate collapse. You shrug at injustice because you're too tired to fight.

And maybe that's rational. Maybe giving up makes sense.

But here's the question:

**What if despair is just another form of privilege?**

What if the people who can't afford to give up—the 47.9 million, the displaced, the targeted—what if they're still planting trees?

illustration.description: Dithered ink drawing of person planting a seed/tree in barren ground OR hands holding a small flame/light in darkness

panels.heading: PLANTING TREES YOU WON'T SIT UNDER
panels.content:
2,000 years ago, the world was collapsing.

Roman occupation. Political violence. Economic exploitation. Environmental degradation. Persecution of minorities.

The early Christians had every reason to despair.

But they didn't.

They planted churches. They shared resources. They cared for the sick, fed the hungry, housed the displaced.

They acted as if the work mattered, even when the outcome was uncertain.

**That's hope.**

Not "it'll be fine."

But "I will be faithful even if it's not fine."

Hope is what you do when optimism dies.

panels.heading: FAITHFULNESS AS RESISTANCE
panels.content:
Jesus said:

**"Whatever you did for the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me."**

Feed the hungry. Welcome the stranger. Care for the sick. Visit the prisoner.

Not because it'll fix the system. But because **faithfulness is resistance.**

Planting a tree you'll never sit under is an act of defiance against despair.

Sharing food when SNAP gets cut is kingdom economics.

Building community when institutions collapse is hope enacted.

You're not saving the world. But you're participating in God's renewal of it.

And that's enough.

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

Optimism is dead. I can't pretend it'll all work out.

But despair is a luxury I can't afford either.

Teach me hope—the kind that plants trees in scorched earth. The kind that feeds neighbors when systems fail. The kind that acts as if the work matters, even when the outcome is dark.

Let me be faithful in the dark.

Amen.
